bibl.title: Letter from Leonard Wood to Francis V. Greene, August 16, 1899

div1.p: Wood writes concerning the appointment of the Secretary of War. He describes actions taken by the military to avoid yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from Leonard Wood to Francis V. Greene, August 16, 1899
div1.opener:
Santiago de Cuba,
Cuba,August 16th, 1899.
General Francis V. Greene,
No. 11, Broadway,
New York.
My dear General:-
div1.p:
Your letter duly received. It is hardly necessary for me
to say that I should have been delighted to have seen you appointed
Secretary of War, and during my recent visit to the States, when
asked by a very important personage whom I considered to be the
most available and best suited man for this position, I mentioned
General Francis V. Greene of New York.

In the appointment of Mr Root I am pleased to say that we
have a most desirable and excellent secretary, and one in whom we
can all place unlimited confidence, and one from whom we shall ob-
tain the necessary reforms in the War Department.

Mr Day left a short time ago. I was very glad indeed
to see him leave, because the situation was not very favorable here
at that time, and it was very probable that he would have contracted
the disease, had he remained.

Governor Roosevelt wrote me the other day in reference to
his trip to Washington which seems to have been a very pleasant one.

Affairs here are very far from satisfactory as we seem to
be drifting on without any definite line of policy so far as the
next few years are concerned. However, everyone is doing what he
can to further the best interests of our own and the Cuban people.

Yellow fever is practically at an end. I have recommended
the permanent abandonment of hospitals and barracks in the city and
the building of frame structures in the mountains nearby, at an
elevation of about twelve to fourteen hundred feet. Here our
people will be safe and at the same time near enough to perform any
necessary military duty. I hope in the near future to see the gar-
rison of regular troops very much diminished and several regiments
of native troops formed under American officers who have served in
Cuba with distinction.

With kindest regards and many very pleasant recollections of
your thoughtfulness and courtesy during my recent visit to the Uni-
ted States,
